newsitem.title: CHINA: China warns against cashing in on Hong Kong theme.
newsitem.headline: China warns against cashing in on Hong Kong theme.

text.p: Chinese authorities on Saturday tried to rein in a tide of unofficial commemorative badges and coins issued to cash in on the return of Hong Kong to Beijing's rule.
The Beijing Evening News said only the central bank could issue such coins and government approval was needed to produce or sell badges marking the recovery of the British colony.
"Only the central bank can mint commemorative coins... and no other organisation can produce or issue them," the newspaper said.
"Permission from relevant government departments must be obtained for the use of any major political topic, historical event or depiction of party or government figures."
The newspaper said many organisations had been selling unauthorised items marking the return of Hong Kong.
Under a Sino-British accord signed in 1984, Hong Kong reverts to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, ending more than 150 years of British rule.

China has been holding concerts, contests and exhibits with a Hong Kong theme in a drive to boost public awareness of the occasion. Its main television news programme starts with an announcement of the number of days until the transfer of power.
